children.subject:
+1

Despite being large, we are still an academic department.Our jurisdiction and influence is not an extensive as many students assume.

If the department had the funding, they could certainly start holding talks by prominent researchers/important figures in the tech industry (or even simply giving EECS student groups the means to advertise more broadly) on the areas of campus that historically have not had many EECS events (ex. Sproul Plaza). In a sense, take up the space so that other non-educational/disruptive events cannot occur.

Everyone has the right to protest. Don't forget that Berkeley is not only know for its academics. 

But to be honest, this is not the first protest south side has had. People are going to find a way to protest. While it might be annoying to you, it might mean to world to someone else.
Good point.  While the protests are annoying, expensive, maddening and drive us completely up the wall.... let's not forget we are SO blessed and fortunate that they are given a priority to continue.

How do you think the EECS department could prevent this from happening? The only possible way I can think of to stop protestors from occupying classrooms (like Wheeler yesterday) is to have police bar them from entering the school buildings, which is neither legal or practical. 

Seems like you could start a conservation elsewhere, such as with school admin or UCPD

history.content:
I don't see what "EECS+LLCS is the largest major on campus" has to do with your argument.

All courses have students. CS isn't more important because it has more students.

And, as noted below, this has nothing to do with the department.

If you want to counterprotest or countercounterprotest, go ahead.

I'm getting really annoyed that our campus is being used as an arena for a political showdown. The situation has become so ridiculous that students have been physically barred from getting to class by outsiders, classes which included EECS courses. This is completely contrary to Berkeley's purpose as an educational institution.

EECS+LSCS is the largest major on campus, and furthermore a sizable proportion of the student population have taken at least one EECS course. Why is the department not doing something to protect the interests of its students? Sproul Plaza should not just be a place for pointless rhetoric over political divisions, but rather a podium for spreading the useful knowledge taught in the EECS curriculum to a greater audience. If we could occupy Sproul with our own ideas, then we would not have to worry about outsiders trying to occupy us.
history.subject: Why are we allowing the recent classroom disruptions to occur?
